stream_context.summary: Kaze works primarily on overworld terrain look-dev: fixing/choosing rock shaders and transitions (including a volcanic island section), planning decals/plants, and dealing with a blocking Fast64 material/viewport bug. He also shares two major project updates: Course 4’s first external beta test results (including a softlock and a disliked plane mission) and a new public RTYI progress-tracker spreadsheet to answer constant progress/release questions. Side discussions include why N64 games looked blurry (research for an upcoming video), the economics of YouTube uploads, and the bootleg cartridge market around ROM hacks.
stream_context.significance_reason: Introduces the first beta test of Course 4 and debuts a public RTYI progress-tracker spreadsheet; both are concrete process milestones and reveal remaining pain points (softlocks, mission redesign, rework expectations, tooling blockers).

findings.summary: Kaze says the sound engine has been completely remade, enabling them to add ambient sound effects broadly; he has started importing Badub’s sound effects and highlights how subtle looped props (propeller/windmill) make areas feel more alive.
A Fast64 issue is blocking desired blending/viewport behavior ("fast 64 box"/rendering area); Kaze checks the Fast64 forum and finds no fix yet—he was told to use a different approach instead.
Course 4 received its first beta test. Testers liked the course more than Kaze expected, but a major softlock bug appeared and Kaze calls the plane mission "awful," prompting a planned redesign.
Kaze has already discussed Course 4’s plane-mission “damage control” with Vileback and says they have a decent idea for how to replace or salvage the mission concept.

Kaze created and shared a public RTYI progress-tracker spreadsheet (with per-course completion percentages) and plans to tweet it and update it regularly to communicate status without giving a release date.
He reiterates there is no release date—RTYI will release “when it’s done”—and explains that repeated release-date questions are individually innocent but collectively exhausting.
findings.quote: It’s going to release when it’s done, basically.

findings.summary: Kaze is maintaining a bi-weekly YouTube upload pace and is conflicted: he views some uploads as “nonsense” that performs well, but says video production takes time away from the game. He bluntly states he dislikes making videos but does it for income.
findings.quote: No, I hate making videos. But it’s good money.

findings.summary: For overworld/volcanic island visuals, Kaze experiments with rock textures and concludes the more Mario-appropriate approach is to prioritize friendliness over realism (e.g., cutting cliffs shorter and putting grass on top), while preventing players from reaching those grassy caps.

He decides the island should visually separate a volcanic side from a non-volcanic side (different rock looks), and that stripey “layering” should be limited to the geologically plausible areas rather than applied everywhere.
Kaze explains one of his terrain transitions: a transparent decal that fades in using an alpha blend (he describes it as “a decal with Red X Alpha”).
He mentions the “final build” should work on Overdrive and says he plans to investigate and fix the Overdrive crash, expressing confidence but not certainty.

When asked about making the project flashable, Kaze argues it’s hard to prevent but dangerous because it enables a bootleg cartridge industry; he claims bootleggers have likely made very large sums selling repro carts of his work, which also increases his fear of Nintendo retaliation even if he isn’t involved.
findings.quote: I bet my ROM hacks probably made over a million dollars at this point through repro cartridges.

biobak.summary: Kaze notes Course 3 may still get reworked if Biobak wants changes; Kaze considers it finished but expects potential iteration driven by Biobak’s feedback.
Kaze clarifies for chat that “Biobak rework” is primarily graphical updating ("like 90%"), with occasional simple gameplay tweaks that are easy to accommodate.

badub.summary: Kaze begins importing Badub’s sound effects into RTYI and showcases how they enhance ambience now that the sound engine rewrite allows SFX placement throughout levels.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: No, I hate making videos. But it’s good money.
memorable_quotes.context: A candid admission about the economic tradeoff of sustaining YouTube output versus time/energy for RTYI development.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: I bet my ROM hacks probably made over a million dollars at this point through repro cartridges.
memorable_quotes.context: Reveals the scale of the bootleg economy around his work and why flashable/distribution choices feel legally risky.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: It’s going to release when it’s done, basically.
memorable_quotes.context: His definitive stance on RTYI timelines, used to deflect persistent release-date pressure while pointing viewers to the new progress tracker.

key_stories.title: Course 4’s first beta test exposes a softlock and a failing mission
key_stories.summary: Kaze shares the first external playtest results for Course 4: reception was better than he expected, indicating the course direction is working. However, a serious softlock bug and a universally disliked “plane mission” create immediate priorities and force design triage.
key_stories.challenge: A brand-new beta test surfaced a frustrating softlock and confirmed the plane mission concept isn’t fun.
key_stories.process: Kaze reviews tester sentiment, identifies the softlock as a key blocker, and coordinates with Vileback on a “damage control” plan to replace or rework the plane mission.
key_stories.outcome: Course 4 is considered “on the right track,” but the next iteration must fix the softlock and redesign the plane mission to avoid shipping a weak segment.
key_stories.key_quote: The plane mission sucks. So we need to think of something new for the plane mission here.

key_stories.title: Publishing an RTYI progress tracker to answer “when release”
key_stories.summary: To reduce repetitive questions and make progress legible, Kaze publishes a spreadsheet showing per-course completion percentages and plans to update and tweet it. He uses it to reinforce that there is still no release date—only visible progress and future reworks.
key_stories.challenge: Constant public pressure for a release date and repeated “how far along is it?” questions.
key_stories.process: Kaze creates a progress-tracker spreadsheet, shares it live, explains that the course order isn’t final, and frames the tracker as the best available transparency tool.
key_stories.outcome: Viewers get an official progress reference; Kaze sets expectations that the game ships “when it’s done,” with tracking replacing date promises.
key_stories.key_quote: If you want to track progress in RTYI, you can look at this spreadsheet.

key_stories.title: Volcanic island look-dev: choosing Mario-friendly geology over realism
key_stories.summary: While hunting for volcanic rock textures and shader transitions, Kaze realizes realism can make the island harsher and less “Yoshi’s Island.” He pivots toward a friendlier silhouette: grass-topped cliffs, controlled reachability, and a clear visual split between volcanic and non-volcanic sides.
key_stories.challenge: Current rock transitions and textures look “horrid/poopy,” and purely realistic volcanic rock (dark gray/black) clashes with Mario’s palette and readability.
key_stories.process: He consults chat “rock expert” feedback, tests multiple textures, considers where layering/stripes make sense, and then chooses to shorten cliffs and cap them with grass while blocking access.
key_stories.outcome: A decided direction for the island’s macro look (friendliness/readability first), with follow-up work needed on transitions, decals, and color matching across rock sets.
key_stories.key_quote: Maybe it is the right move to say, fuck the rocky parts. We’re putting grass on top.

key_stories.title: Why flashable ROMs invite bootlegs—and legal fear
key_stories.summary: Asked about flashable builds, Kaze explains that enabling easy physical carts fuels a bootleg resale industry. He estimates repro sellers may have already made enormous sums off his work, and worries that this ecosystem increases Nintendo risk even though he isn’t selling carts himself.
key_stories.challenge: Balancing player convenience (flash carts) against bootleg commercialization and potential Nintendo enforcement.
key_stories.process: Kaze describes the bootleg market, notes how difficult it is to truly prevent flashability, and frames restrictions as a defensive move against resale profiteering.
key_stories.outcome: Clear articulation of why distribution decisions are constrained by downstream bootlegging and legal exposure, not just technical feasibility.
key_stories.key_quote: If I don’t prevent people from doing that, then people are going to make bootlegs of my game and sell them.

open_questions.context: Kaze reports repeated softlocks in the first Course 4 beta test and says the plane mission “sucks,” but only hints at a “damage control” plan he discussed with Vileback.
questions: What exactly caused the Course 4 softlock—was it scripting/state, camera, collision, save flags, or mission structure?
How did testers describe the plane mission problem (controls, pacing, objectives, readability), and what evidence convinced you it had to change?
What alternative mission concept did you and Vileback land on, and how did you evaluate it against the original vision for Course 4?

open_questions.topic: RTYI progress tracker methodology and communication strategy
open_questions.context: Kaze shares a spreadsheet with per-course completion percentages, notes “course order is not final,” and references future “reworks,” but doesn’t define what each percentage means or what qualifies as “done.”
questions: How do you decide a course is 75% vs 95%—what categories (layout, art pass, music, bugs, missions, secrets) drive the number?
What are the “next 7 reworks” you alluded to—are they specific courses, global systems, or polish passes?
How has publicly tracking progress changed team planning or community expectations—did it reduce pressure or create new kinds of pressure?

open_questions.topic: Sound engine rewrite and ambient SFX philosophy
open_questions.context: Kaze says the sound engine was “completely remade,” enabling widespread SFX placement, and he demonstrates subtle ambience (propeller/windmill) as an immersion layer people feel more than notice.
questions: What forced the sound engine rewrite—technical debt, feature limitations, performance, tooling, or porting constraints?
How do you decide where to place “felt but unnoticed” ambience versus more noticeable SFX, and how do you test that balance?
What’s the workflow with Badub now—does he deliver raw assets, do you integrate/iterate live, and how do you keep a consistent soundscape across courses?

open_questions.topic: Fast64 blocking issues and pipeline risk
open_questions.context: Kaze can’t fix at least one lighthouse/visual issue because it’s a Fast64 bug, and he’s waiting on tool updates while still needing blend/shader work for terrain transitions.
questions: Which specific Fast64 bug is blocking the lighthouse and blending work, and what would a tool fix need to change?
How often do external toolchain issues like Fast64 become schedule-critical for RTYI, and what’s your fallback when they don’t get fixed?
Have these blockers pushed you to develop internal tools/workarounds, or do you intentionally avoid that to prevent pipeline fragmentation?

open_questions.topic: Bootleg economy impact on release/distribution decisions
open_questions.context: Kaze claims bootlegs of his ROM hacks may have generated over $1M in repro-cart sales and ties that to fear of Nintendo action, shaping how “flashable” he can make releases.
questions: What did you first notice that convinced you repro carts were being sold at scale—was it listings, fan reports, or takedown attempts?
Have you considered any anti-bootleg strategies (personalized builds, checks, licensing language, partnerships) that don’t harm legitimate players?
How do you weigh the risk of Nintendo enforcement against the desire to let fans experience RTYI on real hardware?
